Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Implementing Practical Provably Secure Authenticated Key Exchange for the Post-Quantum World
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cyber security is considered one of the most important aspects of our information technology based society. Key Exchange(KE) is a fundamental cryptographic primitive, and authenticated KE (AKE) is one of the most used cryptographic tools in secure communication protocols (e.g. SSL/TLS, IPSec, SSH) over the Internet. In light of the threat that quantum computers pose to cryptosystems such as RSA and ECC, this project is devoted to the development of secure and efficient AKE alternatives for the post-quantum computer world, which is now considered of a high priority by the US government. This project will help develop new AKEs that have the great potential in cyber security for our society. The success of the project will not only have very significant practical values, but also will have a broad impact on theoretical mathematics and computation. This project will have a significant impact on the collaboration we are developing with the Post-Quantum cryptography group at the National Institute of Standard of Technology, where a significant amount of efforts is devoted to the study of quantum resistant AKEs. The PI will teach and work with undergraduate and graduate students, and recruit students from under represented groups in science.

This project intends to develop AKE schemes but based on problems resistant to quantum computer attacks, in particular, we would like to develop efficient and secure implementations of AKE based on the learning with errors problems (LWE) and ring-LWE (RLWE) problems, as well as the selection of concrete parameters for applications with the goal developing secure and efficient systems for the post-quantum world. Such a system should enjoy the potential benefits of lattice-based constructions such as asymptotic efficiency, conceptual simplicity, worst-case hardness assumptions, and provable security, which makes it perfect for the post-quantum world. This key component of the project is based on several promising innovative ideas coming from preliminary experiments and theoretical results we have established, and this project also includes fundamental new ideas in addressing a diverse set of challenges in the design of AKEs. The results will lead to a better understanding of the fundamentals of the AKEs based on LWE and to methods on how to design more secure and efficient AKEs for practical applications. Our research approach is a synergistic combination of new mathematical ideas and systematic computer experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI of this projected invented the first post-quantum key exchange which is based on the Learning with error problem (LWE). This project was originally intended to implement and test (Ring) learning with errors (LWE)-based authenticated key exchanges and study related mathematical problems including optimization and security-related problems. But due to new discovery of the key reuse leakage problem in this new post-quantum key exchange and the National Institute of Standards of Technology’s new call for the next generation post-quantum cryptographic security standard, the scope of the project was extended to the case of post-quantum key exchange as well. The first outcome of this project is the submission of a post-quantum key exchange proposal to and the National Institute of Standards of Technology (NIST) to compete to become the next generation of post-quantum graphic standards. Here we improved and optimized the original design and tested and implemented the new designs and performed a thorough security analysis. This is actually a result of an intense international collaboration with the research team of my colleague Professor Tsuyoshi Takagi at Tokyo University. The second focus of the research is to deal with key leakage attacks in the case of key reuse of the post-quantum key exchanges. We first fully developed the first complete leakage attack on the LWE key exchange, and developed new efficient method to prevent such attacks, and this new method is called the pasteurization of LWE samples. Then we apply those techniques further to authenticated key exchanges to build new and efficient authenticated key exchanges and their implementations. These research results led to five publications in refereed international conferences in information security and cryptography:


Jintai Ding, Scott R. Fluhrer, Saraswathy RV:
Complete Attack on RLWE Key Exchange with Reused Keys, Without Signal Leakage. ACISP2018: 467-486

 

Xinwei Gao, Jintai Ding, Jiqiang Liu, Lin Li:
Post-Quantum Secure Remote Password Protocol from RLWE Problem. Inscrypt 2017: 99-116


Jintai Ding, Saed Alsayigh, Jean Lancrenon, Saraswathy RV, Michael Snook:
Provably Secure Password Authenticated Key Exchange Based on RLWE for the Post-Quantum World. CT-RSA 2017: 183-204

 

Jintai Ding, Saed Alsayigh, R. V. Saraswathy, Scott R. Fluhrer, Xiaodong Lin:
Leakage of signal function with reused keys in RLWE key exchange. ICC 2017: 1-

 

Xinwei Gao, Lin Li, Jintai Ding, Jiqiang Liu, R. V. Saraswathy, Zhe Liu:
Fast Discretized Gaussian Sampling and Post-quantum TLS Ciphersuite. ISPEC 2017: 551-565

and two publications in international journals:


Xinwei Gao, Jintai Ding, Lin Li, Saraswathy RV, Jiqiang Liu:
Efficient Implementation of Password-based Authenticated Key Exchange from RLWE and Post-Quantum TLS. I. J. Network Security 20(5): 923-930 (2018

 

Xinwei Gao, Jintai Ding, Lin Li, Jiqiang Liu:
Practical Randomized RLWE-Based Key Exchange Against Signal Leakage Attack. IEEE Trans. Computers 67(11): 1584-1593 (2018)

 

We expect these results to have significant practical application to help to ensure the next generation IT system to be secure under quantum computer.

 

The support of this project allowed our team members to exchange ideas and give lectures on our results around the world.

 

For this project, the PI worked clsoely with his Ph.D. students. Two Ph.D. thesis were also finished under the guidance of PI in the related topics of password authenticated key exchange and key reuse leakage problem during this period with partial support from this project. We also attracted some undergraduate students to work with PI on the project. The PI also included some of the results of the project into the cryptography class taught by PI.

 

The results of this project also leads to a new three year international collaboration project with Professor Kwanjo Kim at the Korea Advanced Institute of Technology (KAIST) supported by the US Air Force and Korea government, where we intend to develop authenticated multiparty post-quantum key exchanges. 

 

The works in this project also lead to new ideas in the directions of post-quantum oblivious transformations, which the PI's team is now pursuing.
